Regional—Policy and Advisory Technical Assistance (R-PATA)

Strengthening Local Chambers of Commerce and 
Industry along the East–West Economic Corridor to 
Promote Trade, Investment and Value Chains 
(Financed by the Investment Climate Facilitation Fund under the 
Regional Cooperation and Integration Financing Partnership Facility)  
 
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the Asian Development 
Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status of any territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The proposed regional technical assistance (TA) responds to the recommendations 
made by the leaders of the Greater Mekong Subregion (GMS) countries1 at their 3rd summit 
held in the Lao People's Democratic Republic (Lao PDR) in March 2008, which called for the 
integration of small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) in the GMS into regional value chains 
(RVCs) and global value chains (GVCs).2 These value chains would take advantage of the 
opportunities presented by the GMS transport routes and help expand the economic activities 
beyond the confines of these routes. The 15th GMS Ministerial Conference, held in Thailand in 
June 2009, endorsed the East–West Economic Corridor (EWEC) strategy and action plan, 
which articulated two activities along the EWEC—mapping of RVC and GVC opportunities for 
SMEs, and strengthening the capacity of local chambers of commerce and industry—to respond 
to such opportunities. The proposed TA supports these activities, and is included in the program 
of nonlending products and services for 2009 in the indicative regional cooperation operations 
business plan (2010–2012).3 GMS governments have indicated their concurrence with the TA 
impact, outcome, outputs, implementation arrangements, cost, financing arrangements, and 
terms of reference. The design and monitoring framework of the TA is in Appendix 1.4 
 
2.  The  TA  is  in  line  with  a  strategic  priority  of  the  regional  cooperation  strategy  and 
program of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) for the GMS,5 in terms of integrating national 
markets to promote economic efficiency and private sector development. The TA is also one of 
a  series  of  interventions  by  ADB  and  other  development  partners  that  seek  to  transform 
transport corridors into economic corridors through transport and trade facilitation, logistics and 
urban  development,  and  value  chain  development.  ADB  has  undertaken  several  initiatives 
relating to transport and trade facilitation, which have focused on implementation of a cross-
border transport agreement, development of sanitary and phyto-sanitary and national logistics 
action plans, coordinated border management, and a proposed corridor town development TA. 
The proposed TA will build on the results of the regional TA for Facilitating Cross-Border Trade 
and Investment in the Greater Mekong Subregion,6 which assessed the capacity development 
needs of local GMS chambers of commerce and industry (CCIs). 7 The TA will also build on and

and finally disposal and recycling. Value chains become regional or global when their component activities are 
geographically dispersed across borders to locations in multiple countries, and they become functionally integrated 
into new border-spanning business arrangements (O. Memedovic. 2007. Links between Local Clusters and Global 
Value Chains. Geneva: United Nations Conference on Trade and Development).

their  members,  most  of  which  are  SMEs.  Local  CCIs  can  facilitate  business-to-business  networking,  GVC 
awareness-raising for SMEs, and information dissemination to SMEs. They can link GVC participants, local 
producers and local authorities. Local CCIs will participate in TA training courses, workshops, and trade forums. 
They will act as trainers for SME capacity development training to be provided under future initiatives.

II.  ISSUES 
3.    GMS markets are fragmented, with cross-border flows of trade and investment taking 
place only between major urban centers, or limited to certain nodal points. SMEs account for 
more than 90% of enterprises in Cambodia, the Lao PDR, and Viet Nam and around 65%–75% 
of enterprises in the PRC and Thailand. The majority of SMEs in the GMS are in the agricultural 
sector,  agro-industry  and  agribusiness.  Globalization  provides  an  important  opportunity  to 
integrate SMEs and local producers into RVCs or GVCs. Most SMEs are unaware of (and lack 
access  to)  RVCs  or  GVCs  and  related  international  production  networks.  Local  CCIs  and 
agencies responsible for SME promotion and development can play a critical role in advocating 
for and promoting trade, investment, and SME development and integration into RVCs or GVCs, 
but the capacity of local CCIs is limited and needs to be strengthened. GVC integration is also 
limited by the weak industrial linkage between SMEs and multinational companies in GVCs.  
 
4.    The  completion  of  the  EWEC  transport  infrastructure  provides  a  solid  basis  for 
increased SME business opportunities and cooperation within the GMS with respect to RVCs or  
GVCs and the development of subregional production clusters to increase productivity and 
competitiveness.9 To increase trade flows and integrate SMEs along the corridor into RVCs or 
GVCs, it is important that market-related product linkages among SMEs in relation to RVCs or 
GVCs be established. Strengthened and expanded linkages among key players in the selected 
value chains will increase the trade of goods and services among SMEs along the EWEC, and 
contribute to its transformation into an economic corridor. 
 
5.  Integrating SMEs into value chains can be complicated by the difficulty small, isolated 
SMEs have in becoming part of value chains due their limited (i) internal capacity, (ii) accounting 
structures, and (iii) ability to move upward in and meet the expectations and requirements of the 
value chain. Trade promotion and value chain integration are therefore best pursued through 
SME clusters. In the EWEC, local CCIs and SME promotion and development offices would 
work  with  SME  clusters  to  provide  needed  information  services,  training,  and  other  trade 
promotion measures.  
 
6.  By strengthening the capacity of local CCIs along the EWEC to promote inter-SME trade 
and RVC or GVC-related trade promotion, the TA will add value to ongoing ADB-assisted 
private sector and SME development programs in the Lao PDR and Viet Nam that aim to 
improve the business and investment climate, undertake SME policy and legislative reforms, 
improve the enabling environment for SME development, and expand SME access to finance. 
The  TA  will  complement  value-chain-related  activities  undertaken  by  other  development 
partners in the GMS.10 The TA, in combination with other efforts undertaken by ADB and its 
development partners, will also address key factors limiting SME participation in value chains.

III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
7.   The impact of the TA will be an increase in the market-related product linkages between 
SMEs along the EWEC in relation to regional or global value chains.  
 
8.  The expected outcome of the TA will be increased capacity of local CCIs to promote 
inter-SME and RVC or GVC-related trade.  
 
9.   Increasing the capacity of local CCIs will enable them to help SMEs find markets 
through linkages with SMEs located within or outside the EWEC, or other enterprises linked to 
value chains; over time SME inputs would complement each other, resulting in the expansion of 
market-related product linkages among SMEs in relation to RVCs or GVCs. Market-related 
product linkages include those (i) among SMEs; (ii) between SMEs and larger organizations 
(e.g., international buyers); and (iii) between businesses (SMEs and/or larger enterprises) and 
external  institutions  (e.g.,  governments  and  educational  institutions,  but  in  particular  value 
chains).  Market-related  product  linkages  will  lead  to  increased  awareness  of  market 
opportunities, better appreciation of what is required to respond to such opportunities, initiatives 
aimed at directly and/or indirectly improving the capacity of producers and SMEs to respond to 
markets, and increased awareness of regional and international buyers.   
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
10.  The TA aims to achieve the following key outputs: (i) a training program developed and 
delivered for nine local CCIs11 along the EWEC in promoting inter-SME trade and value-chain- 
related  trade  promotion;  (ii)  action  plans  mapping  value  chain  integration  for  at  least  two 
products; (iii) an action plan on establishing EWEC production clusters; (iv) value-chain-related 
information disseminated to EWEC SMEs; and (v) a value-chain-related trade forum.  The TA 
will therefore undertake the following activities: 
 
11.  Training program for local chambers of commerce and industry. This component 
will (i) analyze a capacity development need assessment for local CCIs, which was conducted 
in 2008 under ADB TA (footnote 6), and design a relevant, efficient and effective training 
program for local CCIs; (ii) undertake consultations with the GMS Business Forum (GMS-BF), 
local CCIs, agencies responsible for SME development and promotion and other stakeholders 
on  the  relevance,  efficiency  and  effectiveness  of  the  training  program  developed;  and  (iii) 
conduct training workshops for nine local EWEC CCIs in (a) promoting inter-SME trade and 
RVC  or  GVC-related  trade  promotion;  (b)  CCI—SME  interaction  in  promoting  cluster 
development; (c) facilitating the establishment of market-related product linkages among SMEs 
along  the  EWEC;  and  (d)  information  management.  A  GMS  institute,  with  close  technical 
                                                                                                                                                          
vegetables, and coffee in the Boloven Plateau, southern Lao PDR. Swiss Import Promotion Program had a number 
of small projects for organic fruit and vegetables, honey and bamboo shoots for Vientiane markets in the Lao PDR 
and activities relating to organic shrimp in Viet Nam. The United Nations Industrial Development Organization 
carried out a project on wood processing and agro-business in central Lao PDR, and assists Cambodia, the Lao 
PDR, and Viet Nam with furniture and wood products standards. 
11 Local  CCIs  are  located  in  selected  provinces  along  the  EWEC: Tak,  Phitsanulok,  Khonkaen,  Kalasin  and 
Mukdahan provinces in Thailand, Savannakhet province in the Lao PDR, and Quang Tri, Hue, and Da Nang 
provinces in Viet Nam.

guidance  and  oversight  from  an  international  CCI  development  specialist,  will  develop  the 
training program.  
 
12.   Action plans mapping value chain integration. This component will (i) build on the 
value chain scoping exercise conducted in 2009 with ADB TA (footnote 8) to carry out a detailed 
value chain feasibility study of agricultural produce, agribusiness and /or agro-processing sector 
in the GMS with high value-chain potential; (ii) undertake consultations with local CCIs, selected 
enterprises, relevant government departments, GVC firms, exporters, suppliers of different tiers 
and  producers  for  the  identified  agricultural  produce,  agribusiness  and/or  agro-processing 
sector; (iii) prepare action plans mapping value chain participation for at least two selected 
products; and (iv) produce 1,000 copies of value-chain-related brochures outlining the ways, 
steps, requirements, and risks in value chain participation.  
 
13.   Action  plan  on  establishing  production  clusters.  This  component  will  (i) collect 
information  on  the  spatial  distribution  of  production  along  the  EWEC,  and  examine  the 
probability  of  organizing  production  clusters  according  to  the  comparative  advantages  and 
strengths of geographic locations; (ii) review studies by other development partners and assess 
the possibility of linking production clusters with the GMS free trade zone, and other special 
economic zones and export-oriented zones; and (iii) prepare an action plan with a detailed 
feasibility study on the establishment of production clusters. 
 
14.  Workshops for small and medium-sized enterprises. This component will (i) design 
the value-chain awareness training workshops based on the value chain analysis, and action 
plans for value chain mapping and cluster development; (ii) undertake consultations with GMS-
BF,  local  CCIs  and  agencies  responsible  for  SME  development  and  promotion  to  identify 
workshop participants and venues, and plan the conduct of the workshops; and (iii) conduct 
workshops  and  prepare  workshop  evaluation  reports.  SMEs  would  be  selected  through 
extensive consultations with CCIs, SME promotion and development offices in the project area, 
GMS-BF,  and  various  stakeholders,  with  a  focus  on  those  generating  value-chain  effects, 
including producers, different tiers of suppliers and higher-end distributors.  
 
15.  Value-chain-related trade forum. This component will (i) prepare a shortlist of SMEs 
based on their comparative advantages and potential to participate in RVCs or GVCs; (ii) 
identify potential value chain retailers, distributors and/or exporters and suppliers to be invited; 
and (iii) organize a value-chain-related trade and investment forum. Invitations to participate in 
the value chain forum will be extended to SMEs that have the potential to (i) transfer value-
added activities to large numbers of small farmer groups, and (ii) be successful models for 
others. The selection will be carried out by CCIs in consultation with the project consultant and 
other stakeholders. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
16.  The TA is estimated to cost $660,000, of which $600,000 will be financed on a grant 
basis  by  the  Investment  Climate  Facilitation  Fund12 under  the  Regional  Cooperation  and 
Integration Financing Partnership Facility, and administered by ADB. The participating GMS 
governments will provide the remaining $60,000 equivalent in kind, in the form of counterpart 
staff, logistical support, and other costs as they may arise. The detailed cost estimates are in 
Appendix 2. 
 
                                                 
12  Established by the Government of Japan.

D.  Implementation Arrangements 
17.   ADB's Southeast Asia Department will be the executing agency for the TA, and will 
report its outcome to the GMS senior officials' meeting and the GMS ministerial conference. 
ADB will closely work with (i) the GMS National Coordinator's Office; (ii) agencies responsible 
for SME development and promotion in the GMS countries; (iii) GMS-BF; and (iv) central and 
local CCIs. The GMS-BF and local CCIs will be involved in TA activities such as local CCI 
training program development and delivery, value chain awareness workshops for SMEs and 
the value-chain-related trade forum, including extensive consultations during preparation of the 
action plans for value chain integration mapping and development of the EWEC SME clusters.  
 
18.    The TA will finance 7 person-months (international) and 23 person-months (national) of 
consulting services, for a total of about 30 person-months. International consulting services will 
include 4.5 person-months for an international business development specialist, 1.5 person-
months  for  an  international  CCI  capacity  development  specialist,  1  person-month  for  an 
international trade forum specialist; national consulting services include 8 person-months for a 
national  business  development  consultant,  10 person-months  for  a  national  project 
implementation  support  specialist,  and  5  person-months  for  a  national  event  organizing 
specialist. Due to the variety of expertise required under different components, the consultants 
will be selected on an individual basis. The outline terms of reference for consultants are in 
Appendix 3. The consultants will be hired as individuals and engaged by ADB in accordance 
with  the  Guidelines  on  the  Use  of  Consultants  (2007,  as  amended  from  time  to  time). 
Disbursements under the TA will be done in accordance with ADB's Technical Assistance 
Disbursement Handbook.13 
 
19.   ADB will work closely with international and bilateral agencies in implementing the TA, 
including the European Union Regional Office, German development cooperation through GTZ, 
Japan  External  Trade  Organization,  Japan  International  Cooperation  Agency,  Netherlands 
Development Assistance, the United Nations Economic and Social Commission for Asia and the 
Pacific, the United Nations Industrial Development Organization, and the World Bank.  ADB will 
also cooperate with regional institutions involved in various aspects of capacity development for 
local CCIs, and facilitation of trade and value chain integration. ADB's TA implementation team 
will work in close collaboration with GMS-BF in organizing the training workshops, seminars, 
and trade forum. The TA will be implemented over 20 months from April 2010 to November 
2011. 
 
20.   The expected outputs and outcome evaluation will be disseminated internally through an 
announcement in ADB Today, a brown bag seminar, and workshop; and externally via the ADB 
website and presentations to the GMS investment working group meeting. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
21.   The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved ADB 
administering technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $600,000 to be financed on a 
grant basis by the Investment Climate Facilitation Fund under the Regional Cooperation and 
Integration Financing Partnership Facility for Strengthening Local Chambers of Commerce and 
Industry along the East–West Economic Corridor to Promote Trade, Investment and Value 
Chains, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.   Consultants will be engaged on an individual basis to provide technical services under the 
regional  technical  assistance  (TA);  consultant  inputs  will  total  30  person-months,  including  7 
person-months of international and 23 person-months of national consultant inputs. The consultant 
will report to the Asian Development Bank (ADB) project team leader. The indicative time allocation 
and outline terms of reference follow.  
 
A.  Component 1: Chamber of Commerce and Industry Capacity Development Specialist 
and/or Advisor (international, 1.5 person-months) 
2.  In collaboration with the Greater Mekong Subregion Business Forum (GMS-BF) and a GMS 
institute,  the  consultant  will  (i) analyze  the  results  of  the  survey  of  GMS  local  chambers  of 
commerce  and  industry  (CCIs)  conducted  under  ADB  TA 1  to  identify  areas  of  capacity 
development for local CCIs; (ii) provide assistance to the GMS institute to be engaged for the local 
CCIs capacity development component  in developing CCI training program and provide expert 
opinion on the relevance, efficiency and effectiveness of the training program developed; and 
(iii) participate in critical sessions of the training program.   
3.   The consultant will work with a GMS institute for capacity development to analyze the 
results of the capacity needs assessment of local CCIs and design a relevant, efficient, and 
effective training program for local CCIs in consultation with the GMS-BF, relevant government 
agencies, and other stakeholders. The aim is to produce a train-the-trainer program that will make 
use of local CCIs for sustainable capacity development.  
4.   Deliverable:  a  sustainable  relevant  training  program  developed  and  efficient  training 
courses delivered. 
B.  Components 2 and 3: Business Development Specialist (international, 4.5 person-
months) 
5.  The consultant will: 
(i)  Develop options for pilot projects to build and/or strengthen East–West Economic 
Corridor (EWEC)-related cross-border production linkages in selected value chains 
with significant market potential, including the identification of joint opportunities for 
cross-border production cooperation and related constraints. They should 
(a)  identify the potential for and issues and constraints relating to increased flow 
of trade in goods and services among SMEs along the EWEC;  
(b)  examine  the  potential  for  cross-border  trade  and  investment  along  the 
EWEC and beyond; 
(c)  prepare  action  plans  that  map  two  selected  value  chain  products,  e.g., 
identify key value chain activities, linkages, supporting services, and related 
organizations and institutions. Value mapping should show the key value 
chain functions; the activities and participants in each function throughout 
the chain; input sources; end-market destinations; flows of commodities, 
products  and  services  along  the  chain;  and  interrelationships  among 
participants within the chain; 
(d)  where selection of value chains with significant market potential is based on 
the  potential  interest  of  regional  and  global  buyers,  identify  and  assess 
constraints—including “hard” (e.g., cross-border logistics) and “soft” (e.g., 
                                                 
1  ADB.  2004.  Technical  Assistance  for  Facilitating  Cross-Border  Trade  and  Investment  in  the  Greater  Mekong 
Subregion. Manila (TA 6228-REG).

Appendix 3  11 
cross-border  trade  rules  and  regulations)  constraints—relevant  to  the 
particular value chains selected;  
(e)  prepare  a  brochure  for  distribution  to  SMEs  outlining  how  SMEs  can 
participate in RVCs and GVCs, and that addresses both requirements and 
risks.  
(ii)  In  close  collaboration  with  agencies  responsible  for  SME  promotion  and 
development in the GMS participating countries, explore and develop the potential 
role of enterprise clusters (that are linked to regional and international buyers in the 
selected value chains) as an organizing framework for SME suppliers, and prepare 
an  action  plan  with  a  detailed  analysis  of  the  feasibility  of  establishing  pilot 
production clusters along the EWEC. Include an assessment of key factors, such as  
(a)  existing linkages among GMS producers, and particularly SMEs, that could 
provide the basis for cluster development; 
(b)  the  potential  role  of  industry  and  trade  associations  in  strengthening 
clusters—both domestic and subregional (i.e., GMS-BF); 
(c)  the  potential  domestic  role  of  GMS  governments  in  supporting  cluster  
development; 
(d)  the potential role of regional cooperation among GMS governments related 
to the development of enterprise clusters; and 
(e)  the potential role of public–private sector cooperation in cluster development, 
both domestic and cross-border. 
(iii)  Identify  and  develop  the  potential  role  of  domestic  and  cross-border  economic 
zones (e.g., special economic zones, industrial estates, and bonded warehouses) 
that could support the development and/or strengthening of cross-border production 
linkages and enterprise clusters in the selected value chains. 
(iv)  Prepare and conduct two workshops aimed at strengthening the understanding 
and/or capabilities of GMS SME producers in the selected value chains. Depending 
on the level of preparation and experience of GMS producers in the selected value 
chains, these workshops could be either “familiarization workshops” (e.g., focusing 
on the general structure and dynamics of particular value chains) or more focused 
operationally relevant workshops (e.g., focusing on issues such as certification, 
packaging,  shipping,  and  logistics).  Preparing  and  conducting  the  workshops 
includes activities such as 
(a)  engaging the participation of GMS SMEs in the workshop; 
(b)  coordinating with appropriate industry and trade associations, both domestic 
and cross-border (e.g., GMS-BF); 
(c)  engaging the participation of GMS governments; 
(d)  engaging the participation of relevant regional and international buyers; 
(e)  preparing a workshop agenda; 
(f)  assisting in the conduct  of the workshop; and  
(g)  preparing  follow-up  action  plans  related  to  value  chain  and  cluster 
development. 
(v)  Provide professional inputs relevant to the preparation and organization of the GMS 
investment working group, the agenda of which includes integration into GVCs. 
 
6.  Deliverables: (i) an action plan on value chain mapping; (ii) an action plan on the potential 
of developing production clusters; (iii) RVC/GVC brochures; and (iv) two RVC/GVC workshops 
conducted.

12  Appendix 3 
 
C.  Component 4: Value-Chain-Related Trade Forum Specialist (international, 1 person-
month) 
 
7.   The consultant will  prepare and conduct a trade forum focusing on the selected value 
chains and aimed at strengthening linkages between GMS SME producers and regional and global 
buyers. The trade forum is intended to be a key mechanism through which GMS SMEs can learn 
about market requirements and opportunities, and regional and global buyers can learn about 
GMS SME capabilities. This should include activities such as 
(i)  engaging the participation of various entities and groups in the workshop, including: 
GMS  SMEs,  domestic  and  subregional  (e.g.,  GMS-BF)  industry  and  trade 
associations, GMS governments, and regional and international buyers; 
(ii)  preparing trade forum program (e.g., identifying supporting activities); 
(iii)  assisting in the conduct of the trade forum; and  
(iv)  preparing follow-up action plans (e.g., identifying areas of support to GMS SME 
producers to follow-up trade forum contacts) and follow-up activities to strengthen 
potential linkages (e.g., trade missions to and/or from the GMS). 
 
8.   Deliverable: a successful value-chain-related trade forum prepared and organized. 
D.  National Business Development Consultant (8 person-months) 
 
9.  The consultant will  
(i)  assist the international consultant responsible for developing the training program 
for local CCIs along the EWEC to coordinate with the GMS-BF, local CCIs, the GMS 
institute, and SME development and promotion agencies in the development  and 
delivery of the local CCI training program;  
(ii)  assist in collecting information and materials from various multilateral, bilateral and 
national agencies in the region for use in preparing value chain and production 
cluster action plans;  
(iii)  carry out desk research and analyze existing secondary data;  
(iv)  together with the international consultant, carry out an analysis of the structure, type 
of linkages, and governance pattern of the selected GVC, and the addition of value 
at each major step where an input or process changes the price of the product;  
(v)  assist the international consultant in analyzing the market system and business 
environment in which the subsector and firms operate to identify primary drivers and 
constraints  affecting  the  ability  of  GMS  farmers  and  SMEs  to  take  part  in  the 
selected GVCs;  
(vi)  assist  the  international  consultant  in  analyzing  the  potential  role  of  enterprise 
clusters as an organizing framework for SME suppliers, and linkages to regional and 
international buyers in the selected value chains;  
(vii)  participate in training courses and workshops organized under the TA as requested; 
and  
(viii)  provide inputs and coordinate with the expert teams in preparing and submitting 
various technical reports under the TA. 
 
E.  National Project Implementation Support Specialist (10 person-months) 
 
10.  The specialist will 
(i)  interact with the expert teams under the TA in planning, preparing, and conducting 
country consultation meetings;  
(ii)  liaise with the GMS-BF, local CCIs and EWEC government agencies and with the 
private  sector  in  preparing  background  and  issue  papers  and  in  firming  up

Appendix 3  13 
appointments, and interact with the ADB project officer in successfully implementing 
the TA;  
(iii)  provide support to the various expert teams under the TA in undertaking analytical 
studies, collecting data and detailed information (rules, regulations, and guidelines, 
etc.) covering trade, investment, and selected value chains under the TA;  
(iv)  provide support in planning and preparing for the field visits of the expert teams, in 
preparing  consultation  meetings  in  the  participating  countries,  and  in  planning, 
preparing, and conducting workshops and related meetings to be held under the TA;  
(v)  prepare  training,  workshop,  and  forum  reports,  including  reports  on  project 
implementation progress, issues, project expenditure, and TA budget utilization;  
(vi)  perform administrative and secretariat support as requested by the project officer; 
and  
(vii)  provide  other  support  required  for  implementation  of  the  TA,  and  address 
implementation issues as they arise. 
 
F.  National Event Organizing Specialist (5 person-months) 
 
11.  The specialist will  
(i)  assist in preparing and coordinating events, training courses and/or activities under 
the TA, including making arrangements relating to the conduct of the courses, 
workshops, meetings and value-chain-related trade forum;  
(ii)  coordinate with GMS-BF, local CCIs, the private sector and relevant government 
agencies in relation to organizing training courses, workshops, meetings, and the 
trade forum;  
(iii)  provide administrative and secretariat support to the project team;  
(iv)  assist the project team in collecting and organizing information needed for preparing 
training courses, workshops, and forum reports; and  
(v)  assist with other project-related work.
